newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS - MAY 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS - MAY 23.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek general press:

--The national health system - intricately connected to the ailing pension system - is suffering from the same dire financial straits and needs immediate treatment, the OECD says. The OECD report stresses that despite increased spending, the national health system is not performing or offering what it is supposed to.

--The Athens Stock Exchange has seen three trillion drachmas in turnover since January, a fact which underlines the trend amongst investors to seek alternatives in the wake of the fall in interest rates.
--Conservative opposition New Democracy yesterday said the internal priorities in ruling party PASOK wwere having a dangerous effect on Greece's stance on relations with Turkey.

--Today's meeting of European Union leaders in Noordwijk is considered to be critical for Greece as Athens attempts to get some form of binding commitment on the security of the bloc's external borders.
--Reports from Tirana allege that Italy's ambassador has been conferring with Albanian President Sali Berisha's right-hand man Tritan Sehu, charges the Italian diplomat has denied.
--A 28-year-old police officer was charged with premeditated murder yesterday for the murder of his colleague Nikos Markakis in the Greek consulate at Gjirokaster earlier this week.
--George Koskotas, the man in the middle of the embezzlement scandal at the Bank of Crete in the mid- to late-80s, may be out of jail in as little as three years.
--The defence ministry is preparing radical changes to compulsory military service in the bill to be voted on by Parliament in mid-June.
--Mobile phone companies have set off a price war for their share of the market in 1997, estimated to be worth 300 billion drachmas.
--The US's particular concern about Greek-Turkish relations is purported to be behind plans to appoint US State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns to the position of US ambassador.
--The Communist Party of Greece's leader Aleka Papariga has condemned recent statements by Deputy Foreign Minister George Papandreou on the need to legalise "soft" drugs.
--A record number of candidates will be sitting for university entrance examinations this year. --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
